Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The award will provide support for early career scientists to attend The Allied Genetics Conference (TAGC) on April 22-26, 2020 in the Washington D.C. metro area. The conference will bring together over 4000 US and international investigators to share scientific discoveries, technological advances and educational experiences that advance biological research. A major goal of TAGC is to reintegrate distinct communities of geneticists who focus on different model organisms (e.g., C. elegans, Drosophila, Xenopus, Zebrafish, etc.) through seminars, poster sessions, workshops and discussions that are organized by shared scientific themes. In addition, several career development and skills workshops targeted toward undergraduate-to-mid-career scientists will promote workforce development and diverse participation in STEM fields.

Advances in genetics have opened up new avenues of discovery and yielded technological applications for decades. Now, revolutionary advances in the analysis of genome variation are providing new insights into complex traits; quantitative genetics promise progress on many challenges, including securing the world's food supply; new technologies offer insights into the effects of genetic variation in single cells; genome synthesis and engineering expand the variety of organisms that can be studied and harnessed for materials production. These are but a few of the valuable outcomes of multi-disciplinary research in the field of genetics. The conference will promote progress by facilitating discussions and fostering collaborations among the participants.

This project is jointly funded by the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences - Genetic Mechanisms and Systems and Synthetic Biology Clusters, and by the Division of Environmental Biology - Evolutionary Processes Cluster.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Much of what we know about how cells and organisms work has come from experimentation on a few select organisms that are models for biology. These model organisms include the bacterium E. coli, the yeast S. cerevisiae, the fruit fly Drosophila, the round worm C. elegans, the zebrafish D. rerio, and the mouse.  Researchers studying each of these organisms have long attended meetings focusing on their organism. But the inherent unity of biology calls for bringing these communities together, especially in this age of facile genome sequencing and editing. The Allied Genetics Conference (TAGC) did that, creating opportunities for synergy among researchers in these different communities while still encouraging the community cohesiveness that has made research on these model organisms so productive. Half of the conference consisted of sessions that spanned all the model organisms, presenting recent research on specific topics; the other half of the conference featured organism-specific sessions. The result was a sharing of knowledge, ideas, and methods among these research communities. In addition, early career researchers?graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, junior faculty?benefited from workshops on training and career development; sessions on genetics education brought educators together to share ideas and approaches; diversity of the scientific workforce was encouraged by selection of a diverse group of speakers and a workshop on diversity, equity and inclusion. 

TAGC was intended to be an in-person meeting held April 22-26, 2020. It was more than 2 years in planning when the COVID-19 pandemic forced its cancellation, on March 13. GSA staff immediately went into action to convert TAGC to a virtual meeting, which was held online April 22-25 (i.e., on schedule), with 26 poster sessions held April 27 to May 1, and 14 workshops held between May 7 and July 13. That was a significant feat, as it required rescheduling sessions; coordination with 371 speakers, 122 session chairs and workshop organizers, and 1942 poster presenters; enlistment of several new vendors; testing and implementation of the online platform; implementation of a novel forum for sponsors and exhibitors; wholesale revision of the TAGC website, and more. GSA staff accomplished all of this in only 37 days! Because TAGC was one of the first in-person meetings cancelled due to the pandemic, it was also one of the first (possibly the first) conference held entirely online.

The result was a remarkably smooth meeting attended by 9,861 people! It consisted of 371 oral presentations, 634 poster presentations, and 14 workshop sessions. A survey of participants indicated that 92% learned information to inspire their science and 75% learned about a new tool, method, or technique; a clear majority (~62%) said the conference greatly exceeded or exceeded their expectations.

More information about TAGC2020 is available at: https://genetics-gsa.org/tagc-2020/
